questions.title: Signal Amplitude Analysis with Noise
questions.question_text: When analyzing a noisy sinusoidal signal with amplitude $A = 3\,\text{V}$ using peak detection, how does the measured amplitude compare to the true value?
choices: Varies with each measurement due to random noise
Both B and C are correct
questions.correct_answer: Both B and C are correct
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Random noise causes measurement variability while keeping values relatively close to the true amplitude of $3\,\text{V}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Consider how random noise affects peak detection: it creates variability while keeping measurements near the true value.

questions.title: Phase Shift Effect on Amplitude
questions.question_text: For a sinusoid $A \cdot \sin(2\pi ft + \phi)$, what happens to the measured amplitude when phase $\phi$ changes from $\pi/4$ to $\pi/2$?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Phase shift $\phi$ only affects timing, not the maximum amplitude $A$ of the sinusoid.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Phase $\phi$ shifts the signal in time but doesn't change the peak amplitude $A$.

questions.title: OOP Design Pattern Recognition
questions.question_text: Two classes - SignalGenerator and SignalAnalyzer - model real-world instruments with distinct responsibilities. This exemplifies which OOP principle?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Abstraction creates simplified models of complex real-world entities with clearly defined interfaces.
questions.feedback_incorrect: These classes model real instruments as abstract entities with specific responsibilities - this is abstraction.

questions.title: Aliasing in Video Sampling
questions.question_text: A fan rotating at $60\,\text{Hz}$ is recorded at $50$ frames/second. What aliasing effect occurs?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Undersampling at $f_s < 2f_0$ creates aliasing where $60\,\text{Hz}$ appears as $10\,\text{Hz}$ in reverse direction.
questions.feedback_incorrect: When sampling rate $f_s < 2f_0$, aliasing causes apparent reverse rotation at $|f_s - f_0|\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.title: Stroboscopic Effect Definition
questions.question_text: In video systems, aliasing creates _______ effects where fast-moving objects appear to move erratically due to insufficient sampling.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Stroboscopic effects result from temporal aliasing in video sampling systems.
questions.feedback_incorrect: This visual phenomenon caused by undersampling is called the stroboscopic effect.

questions.title: Nyquist Frequency Calculation
questions.question_text: For a sampling frequency $f_s = 10\,\text{kHz}$, calculate the maximum signal frequency that can be accurately represented using the Nyquist criterion $f_{max} = f_s/2$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $f_{max} = f_s/2 = 10\,\text{kHz}/2 = 5\,\text{kHz} = 5000\,\text{Hz}$ per Nyquist-Shannon theorem.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Apply Nyquist criterion: maximum frequency $= f_s/2 = 10\,\text{kHz}/2 = 5\,\text{kHz}$.

questions.title: Information Loss in Undersampling
questions.question_text: What occurs when a signal is sampled below the Nyquist rate $f_s < 2f_{max}$?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Sampling below Nyquist rate causes irreversible information loss through frequency aliasing.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Undersampling causes aliasing, making perfect signal reconstruction impossible.

questions.title: Digital Audio Sampling Requirements
questions.question_text: For CD-quality audio covering $20\,\text{Hz}$-$20\,\text{kHz}$, why is $44.1\,\text{kHz}$ sampling used?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $f_s = 44.1\,\text{kHz} > 2 \times 20\,\text{kHz}$ satisfies Nyquist criterion for full audio spectrum capture.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Sampling at $44.1\,\text{kHz}$ ensures $f_s > 2f_{max} = 40\,\text{kHz}$ to prevent aliasing per Nyquist theorem.

questions.title: Aliasing Condition
questions.question_text: Aliasing occurs when the sampling frequency $f_s$ is less than twice the highest signal frequency: $f_s < 2f_{max}$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! This violates the Nyquist-Shannon sampling theorem, causing aliasing distortion.
questions.feedback_incorrect: The Nyquist criterion requires $f_s \geq 2f_{max}$ to prevent aliasing.

questions.title: Signal Reconstruction Process
questions.question_text: In digital signal processing, 'reconstruction' refers to:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Reconstruction uses interpolation to rebuild continuous signals from discrete sample points.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Reconstruction is the process of converting discrete samples back to continuous-time signals.

questions.title: Aliasing Signal Distortion
questions.question_text: When aliasing occurs, the original signal becomes _______ and perfect reconstruction becomes impossible.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Aliasing introduces irreversible frequency distortion to the sampled signal.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Aliasing causes signal distortion that cannot be corrected post-sampling.

questions.title: Class Inheritance Implementation
questions.question_text: Which MATLAB syntax correctly implements class Vehicle inheriting from a superclass Transportation?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! MATLAB uses the < operator to specify inheritance: classdef ChildClass < ParentClass
questions.feedback_incorrect: MATLAB inheritance syntax uses < operator: classdef Vehicle < Transportation

questions.title: Phase Relationship Analysis
questions.question_text: Given two sinusoids with $90^\circ$ phase difference, which statement is correct?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Phase difference of $90^\circ = \pi/2\,\text{rad}$ can represent either $+90^\circ$ lead or $-90^\circ$ lag depending on reference.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Phase relationships are relative - the same $90^\circ$ difference can be interpreted as leading or lagging.

questions.title: Audio Aliasing Artifacts
questions.question_text: In digital audio, aliasing introduces unwanted _______ components not present in the original signal.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Aliasing creates phantom frequency components through spectral folding effects.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Aliasing generates spurious frequency components due to undersampling.

questions.title: Fourier Transform Frequency Resolution
questions.question_text: For an $N = 1024$-point FFT with sampling frequency $f_s = 8192\,\text{Hz}$, calculate the frequency resolution $\Delta f = f_s/N$ in Hz.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $\Delta f = f_s/N = 8192\,\text{Hz}/1024 = 8\,\text{Hz}$ frequency bin spacing.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Frequency resolution: $\Delta f = f_s/N = 8192/1024 = 8\,\text{Hz}$ per bin.

questions.title: Phase Leading Definition
questions.question_text: For sinusoids $y_1(t) = A_1\sin(\omega t + \phi_1)$ and $y_2(t) = A_2\sin(\omega t + \phi_2)$, if $\phi_1 > \phi_2$, which statement is correct?
choices: $y_1$ reaches its peak value earlier in time
$y_1$ is shifted left on the graph
questions.correct_answer: $y_1$ reaches its peak value earlier in time
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Leading phase $\phi_1 > \phi_2$ means earlier peak occurrence in the time domain.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Phase shift $\phi$ only affects timing, not frequency $\omega$ or amplitude $A$.

questions.title: Nyquist Rate for 1 kHz Signal
questions.question_text: A signal contains frequencies up to $f_{max} = 1\,\text{kHz}$. What is the minimum Nyquist sampling rate $f_s$?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Nyquist criterion requires $f_s > 2f_{max} = 2 \times 1\,\text{kHz} = 2\,\text{kHz}$ to prevent aliasing.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Nyquist-Shannon theorem: sampling frequency must exceed twice the maximum signal frequency.

questions.title: Aliasing Prevention Scenarios
questions.question_text: Which sampling scenario guarantees NO aliasing for a signal with bandwidth $B = 8\,\text{kHz}$?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Only oversampling with $f_s > 2B = 16\,\text{kHz}$ prevents aliasing per Nyquist criterion.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Undersampling ($f_s < 2B$) and critical sampling ($f_s = 2B$) both risk aliasing.

questions.title: Signal Reconstruction Importance
questions.question_text: Why is sampling above the Nyquist rate $f_s > 2f_{max}$ crucial for digital signal processing?
choices: Ensures perfect signal reconstruction without aliasing
questions.correct_answer: Ensures perfect signal reconstruction without aliasing
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Nyquist criterion guarantees sufficient information capture for accurate reconstruction.
questions.feedback_incorrect: The primary purpose is preventing aliasing distortion, enabling faithful signal reconstruction.

questions.title: Minimum Sampling Rate Calculation
questions.question_text: A signal has maximum frequency component $f_{max} = 5\,\text{kHz}$. Calculate the minimum practical sampling rate in kHz to avoid aliasing.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $f_s > 2f_{max} = 2 \times 5\,\text{kHz} = 10\,\text{kHz}$, so $f_s \geq 10.1\,\text{kHz}$ satisfies Nyquist criterion.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Apply Nyquist theorem: $f_s$ must be greater than $2 \times 5\,\text{kHz} = 10\,\text{kHz}$.

questions.title: Perfect Reconstruction Limitations
questions.question_text: Sampling slightly above the Nyquist rate ($f_s \approx 2.01f_{max}$) guarantees perfect signal reconstruction in all practical systems.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Real systems have noise, non-ideal filters, and quantization effects that limit perfect reconstruction.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Practical limitations like thermal noise, filter roll-off, and finite precision prevent perfection.

questions.title: Anti-Aliasing Filter Design
questions.question_text: For a signal sampled at $f_s = 16\,\text{kHz}$, calculate the maximum anti-aliasing filter cutoff frequency $f_c$ in kHz.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $f_c$ should be slightly below $f_s/2 = 16\,\text{kHz}/2 = 8\,\text{kHz}$ to prevent aliasing.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Anti-aliasing filter cutoff: $f_c \leq f_s/2 = 16\,\text{kHz}/2 = 8\,\text{kHz}$

questions.title: Nyquist Rate Condition
questions.question_text: To avoid aliasing, the sampling frequency $f_s$ must be _______ twice the highest signal frequency: $f_s$ _____ $2f_{max}$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Nyquist-Shannon theorem requires $f_s > 2f_{max}$ for alias-free sampling.
questions.feedback_incorrect: The strict inequality $f_s > 2f_{max}$ is essential to prevent frequency folding.

questions.title: Oversampling Benefits
questions.question_text: What is the primary advantage of sampling at $f_s \gg 2f_{max}$ (significant oversampling)?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Oversampling allows simpler, less steep anti-aliasing filters with wider transition bands.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Higher $f_s$ creates guard bands, making filter design less critical for aliasing prevention.

questions.title: Anti-Aliasing Filter Placement
questions.question_text: Where should an anti-aliasing filter with cutoff $f_c = f_s/2$ be positioned in a sampling system?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Anti-aliasing filters must be analog filters placed before sampling to remove high frequencies.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Aliasing prevention requires analog filtering before the sampling operation occurs.
